bibl.title: The Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion. (1861–65.)
bibl.editor: Surgeon General Joseph K. Barnes, United States Army

taxonomy.bibl: Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion

keywords.term: wounds and injuries of the chest
penetrating gunshot wounds of the chest
gunshot penetrating fractures of the sternum
ball entered between second and third ribs, fractured sternum

revisionDesc.change: additional proofing of transcription and encoding
case text extracted and transformed from larger file
initial checking of OCR text against PDF; encoded

body.p: CASE.—Private P. H. B——, Co. C, 147th Pennsylvania Volunteers, was wounded at Chancellorsville, May 2d, by a conoidal musket-ball, which entered between the second and third ribs, on the right side, two inches from the median line, fractured the sternum, and lodged beneath it. The wound bled profusely, but the hæmorrhage was arrested by pressure The patient was conveyed to Douglas Hospital, Washington, on May 8th, and died the following day. He had hæmoptysis and the symptoms of traumatic pneumonia. The pathological specimen, contributed to the Army Medical Museum by Assistant Surgeon W. Thomson, U. S. A., is figured in the adjoining wood-cut (FIG. 226.)

figure.head: FIG. 226.—Superior portion of sternum fractured by a ball which is attached. Spec. 1073, Sect. I, A. M. M.
